Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2018 Conference on Cryptographic Hardware and Embedded Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal supports ten students for their travel to attend the Cryptographic Hardware and Embedded Systems (CHES) conference, to be held in Amsterdam, the Netherlands in September 2018. CHES is one of the leading international conferences on research on both design and analysis of cryptographic hardware and software implementations. The conference is a premier venue for new results from the research community as well as from the industry. Participation in conferences such as CHES is an extremely important part of graduate students' research and career development, providing the opportunity for them to present their own work, attend panel and keynote speech sessions, interact with peers and senior researchers, and exposure to leading edge work in all aspects of cryptographic hardware and security in embedded systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provides opportunities for selected students to attend the 2018 Cryptographic Hardware and Embedded Systems conference (CHES 2018), held in Amsterdam, the Netherlands in September 2018. The Cryptographic Hardware and Embedded Systems (CHES) conference is the premier venue for research on both design and analysis of cryptographic hardware and software implementations. As an area conference of the International Association for CryptologicResearch (IACR), CHES bridges the cryptographic research and engineering communities, and it attracts participants from academia, industry, government and beyond. The IACR is a non-profit organization devoted to supporting the promotion of the science of cryptology. 

CHES 2018 takes place in Amsterdam, the Netherlands.The costs of participating at the conference includes a registration fee (around 300 dollars for students) and travel costs (about USD 1000 for a return flight to Amsterdam from the US) and lodging (about USD 100 per day). The above mentioned costs are prohibitive for many talented students and a grant is necessary. This is especially true when students do not have a publication at CHES, which means that the incurred travel cost is harder to justify through an existing research grant. 

Through a competitive process, eight students have been selected from six US universities to attend CHES 2018. They met with other researchers in the research field and networked with potential employers. The students were also able to learn about the most recent developments in the area.

The student selection process used a formal application including a review by an external selection committee. The selection committee emphasized support for female students and underrepresented groups. Four out of eight supported students were female. The financial aid helped the travel and lodging of selected students.
